org.nosco
Interface Query<T extends Table>

Type Parameters:
T - the type of object this will return
All Superinterfaces:
java.lang.Iterable<T>
public interface Query<T extends Table>
extends java.lang.Iterable<T>

The Query interface is the center of the Nosco API.   When you generate your JAR file (with org.nosco.ant.CodeGenerator) each object gets its own static Query instance.   For example, if your database table looked like this:

some_class
idname
123my name
456your name

The CodeGenerator would create the following for you (simplified): 

  public class SomeClass extends Table {
     final static Query<SomeClass> ALL = new Query<SomeClass>();
     final static Field<Integer> ID = new Field<Integer>();
     final static Field<String> NAME = new Field<String>();
  }
The constant SomeClass.ALL will generally be your starting point for all queries expected to return SomeClass objects.   For example, if you wanted to iterate over all of them you could do this: 
  for (SomeClass x : SomeClass.ALL)
     System.out.println(x);
If you only want a specific one (assuming "id" was the primary key for the table) you could do this: 
  SomeClass x = SomeClass.ALL.get(SomeClass.ID.eq(123)))
SomeClass.ID is a Field<Integer>. All Field<R> objects contain a eq(<R> x) which returns a Condition object. (here passed into Query.get(Condition... c))   Similarly: 
  for (SomeClass x : SomeClass.ALL.where(SomeClass.NAME.like("%me%")))
     System.out.println(x);
would print out all rows named like "me".

Author:
Derek Anderson

iterator
 

Method Detail

where

Query<T> where(Condition... conditions)
Adds conditions to the query. Usually conditions are created off the fields of tables. Example: SomeClass.SOME_FIELD.eq("abc") would return a Condition. So for a full query: SomeClass.ALL.where(SomeClass.SOME_FIELD.eq("abc")) Multiple conditions are ANDed together.

Parameters:
conditions -
Returns:

get

T get(Condition... conditions)
Returns the only element that matches the conditions. If more than one match, throws a RuntimeException. Equivalent to .where(conditions).getTheOnly()

Parameters:
conditions -
Returns:

count

int count()
          throws java.sql.SQLException
Returns the database-calculated count of the query. Does not download the objects into the JVM. Much faster than .asList().size() or counting the objects yourself.

Returns:
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

size

int size()
         throws java.sql.SQLException
Same as .count()

Returns:
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

exclude

Query<T> exclude(Condition... conditions)
Excludes elements that match the conditions. Equivalent to: .where(condition.not())

conditions -
Returns:

orderBy

Query<T> orderBy(Field<?>... fields)
Sets the ordering of the database query. For descending order, see: .orderBy(DIRECTION, fields)

with

Query<T> with(Field.FK... fields)
Joins on foreign keys. FKed objects are populated under the .getFK() style methods. Avoids O(n) SQL calls when accessing FKs inside a loop.

Parameters:
fields -
Returns:

deferFields

Query<T> deferFields(Field<?>... fields)
Don't include the following fields in the select statement. Note: The returned object will still contain a .getField() method. If it is called another SQL call will be made to fetch this value. (assuming the PK was not also excluded with this call)

Parameters:
fields -
Returns:

onlyFields

Query<T> onlyFields(Field<?>... fields)
Only include the following fields in the select statement. Note: The returned object will still contain all .getField() methods. If any are called that were not in this list, another SQL call will be made to fetch each value. (assuming the PK was included with this call)

Parameters:
fields -
Returns:

latest

T latest(Field<?> field)
Returns the last value that would be returned by the query. Same as: .orderBy(DESCENDING, field).top(1).getTheOnly()

Parameters:
field -
Returns:

first

T first()
Gets the first item in the query. Same as: .top(1).getTheOnly()

Returns:

isEmpty

boolean isEmpty()
                throws java.sql.SQLException
Returns whether the SQL returned any rows or not. Same as: .count() == 0

Returns:
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

update

int update()
           throws java.sql.SQLException
Executes and update statement populated w/ data from .where() and .set(). Example: SomeClass.ALL.set(SomeClass.SOME_FIELD, "xyz") .where(SomeClass.SOME_FIELD.eq("abc")) .update();

Returns:
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

deleteAll

int deleteAll()
              throws java.sql.SQLException
Deletes all rows matching data set with: .where() Example: SomeClass.ALL.where(SomeClass.SOME_FIELD.eq("abc")).deleteAll() Use with caution!

Returns:
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

org.nosco.Statistics stats(Field<?>... field)
Not implemented yet.

Parameters:
field -
Returns:

all

java.lang.Iterable<T> all()
Returns an Iterable for this query. Not usually necessary as the Query itself is Iterable, but useful if you want to prevent further filtering or updating for some reason.

Returns:

none

java.lang.Iterable<T> none()
Returns an always-empty Iterable. I'm not sure this has any practical use, but it seemed to be a good corollary to: .all()

Returns:

orderBy

Query<T> orderBy(Constants.DIRECTION direction,
                 Field<?>... fields)
Same as .orderBy(fields), but allows you to specify the direction. Note: The direction is applied to all the fields. to specify different directions to different fields, chain the calls like this: SomeClass.ALL.orderBy(DESCENDING, SomeClass.SOME_FIELD).orderBy(ASCENDING, SomeClass.SOME_OTHER_FIELD)

Parameters:
direction -
fields -
Returns:

set

Query<T> set(Field<?> key,
             java.lang.Object value)
Sets the field to the given value. Chainable. Does not execute any SQL until .update() is called.

Parameters:
key -
value -
Returns:

set

Query<T> set(java.util.Map<Field<?>,java.lang.Object> values)
Same as calling .set(key, value) for each entry in the Map.

Parameters:
values -
Returns:

insert

java.lang.Object insert()
                        throws java.sql.SQLException
Inserts the values set by .set(key,value). Note: May be easier to create the object with new SomeClass(), then call its setter methods and then .insert() in it.

Returns:
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException

getTheOnly

T getTheOnly()
Returns the only object returned by this query. If multiple rows are returned, throws a RuntimeException.

Returns:

asList

java.util.List<T> asList()
Runs the query, populating a list with all the values returned. Useful if you need non-linear access to your objects, but take note all objects must be able to fit into memory at the same time.

Returns:

asSet

java.util.Set<T> asSet()
Same as asList(), but puts them into a HashSet.

Returns:

sumBy
